title: Survey of New Cola
question_text:
Soft drink manufacturers want to introduce a new flavor of spicy cola to compete with the leading brand of cola.
They went to a local shopping mall and administered a blind taste test that included the new spicy cola and the leading cola brand.
They surveyed $100\text{ subjects}$, and gave each of them an unmarked cup of each cola, in randomized order. The researchers found that $56$ liked the new cola better.
This is an example of

choices.text: A blocking experiment, where cola type is a block.

solution:
We know that this is an experiment because a treatment is applied, however it is done blindly.

Choice 'E' is correct; the experiment is single blind, as only the subjects do not know which cola is which.

Explanation of Distractors

Choices 'A'and 'C' are incorrect; treatments are imposed on the subjects, specifically the new cola and leading cola, so this is an experiment, not a survey or a study. Whether the individuals are approached or volunteer, this does not fall under the category of a survey or study.

Choice 'B' is incorrect; this is an experiment, but there is nothing to suggest that it is double blind; if this experiment were double blind, then those distributing the cola and recording the results would not know which cola is which.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; there is no blocking performed in this experiment; the subjects are not divided up in any sort of manner based on different characteristics.
